Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Prevailing sentiment: Tipping culture in the U.S. feels overextended and coercive. Many want tipping to be optional and tied to quality of service rather than expected for every transaction.

  • Compensation and policy: Strong support for paying workers a livable base wage so income doesn’t rely on tips. Ideas include ending the tip credit, raising minimum wages (often cited around $15), integrating a modest service charge into bills, or increasing menu prices to fund fair pay. A few suggest not taxing tips.

  • Scope of tipping: Many want tipping largely limited to full-service restaurants and clear, labor-intensive services—not counter service, pickup, drive-thru, or minimal-contact transactions.

  • Voluntariness and timing: Tips should be earned and requested only after service is rendered. Mandatory tipping is broadly opposed; service-based discretion is preferred.

  • Point-of-sale practices: Widespread frustration with intrusive tablet prompts and social pressure. Suggested fixes include less aggressive defaults, an obvious “no tip” option on the first screen, and only presenting tipping when meaningful service was provided.

  • Alternative structures: Some propose fixed-dollar tips instead of percentages, standardizing suggested amounts, or providing small acknowledgments (thank-you notes, future-use coupons) when tips are given.

  • Divergent views: A minority favors mandatory tipping or universal adoption to ensure worker income; others argue tipping is a strong performance incentive and continue to tip generously.

  • Core tension: Commenters balance empathy for underpaid workers with fatigue over constant tipping requests. The broad direction favored is shifting responsibility for fair pay to employers and reserving tipping as a voluntary reward for good or exceptional service.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments: - Prevailing sentiment: Tipping culture—especially in the U.S.—is seen as excessive, coercive, and spreading to contexts that don’t involve meaningful service. Many feel pressured by tablet prompts and pre-service tip requests. - Compensation view: Broad agreement that employers should pay a fair, livable wage (ending the sub-minimum “tipped wage”), with tips treated as an optional bonus for good or exceptional service. Several would accept higher menu prices to fund wages. - System reform ideas: - Abolish tipping entirely and fold compensation into prices or a built-in service charge (often cited around 10%). - Keep tipping but make it clearly voluntary, merit-based, and limited mainly to full-service restaurants—not pickup, fast food, or coffee counters. - Standardize aspects (e.g., fixed tip amounts for small bills, clear guidelines by service level) or consider mandatory tips only if wages aren’t livable. - Practical improvements: Show an easy “no tip” option, prompt only after service is delivered, and avoid aggressive default tip screens. Limit who is prompted for tips to roles providing direct service. - Minority perspectives: Some strongly defend tipping as an incentive and tip generously; a few suggest mandatory tipping or argue customers shouldn’t use tipped services if they can’t tip. Other niche suggestions include not taxing tips and offering small thank-you tokens or coupons in return. - Context: Several point to European/Japanese models—higher wages or automatic service charges with minimal tipping—as preferable.

[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: I think it would be better not to have tips but that the restaurant owners paid fairly to their employees. Then they would not depend on tips but would know for certain they earn enough and the same every pay period
